discourse_list.title: Discussion: inclusion of MKR in the collateral list?

content.content: The inclusion of MKR as collateral in Maker (MCD) has been discussed since the very beginning of MCD. The choice has been to not include it because it might create some vicious cycles/loops in the system. This always felt kind of reasonable to me. It is today possible, however, to use 3rd parties solutions to get DAI from your MKR. For example: Aave allows: MKR–>TUSD (borrow) Maker allows: TUSD → DAI (cdp) And these 3rd party solutions will probably just expand in number and liquidity over the next few months. So, my question is: Question: does it still make sense to exclude MKR from the list of assets?
I did a poll a few months ago and the overwhelming consensus was no. I wouldn’t waste your time right now.

thanks, I missed that poll. I will search for it. EDIT: for those interested, the original poll (July) is here:     Signal Request: Should MKR be added as collateral? Since MakerDAO already is primarily backed by ETH I think that if we were able to choose a pragmatic debt ceiling and liquidation ratio that never allowed MKR to be more than a certain percentage of total debt then we would be find. Hello, I am updating this thread. The signal request for MKR as collateral happened in July with: 53% NO, 25% abstain, 23% YES. Several months have passed and several things have changes. Are people still of the idea that MKR would be a bad collateral? In my opinion it has several pros:  it’s possible to get a DAI from MKR using other platforms, anyway. Maker has right now a 6% APY burning action, and as such it appears to be a solid collateral vs many others. the recent sentiment (with 1MKR < 1ETH) is that MKR is properly (or even under-)priced. Hence a good collateral. MKR has been one of the most ‘stable’ coins in the 50coins (by marketcap) with values ranging from 300usd to 800usd in the last 2-3 years.  Beside that, we can of course control the risk by embarking small quantities of MKR, to start with. So, is it perhaps time for a new poll?

Yeah throw up another poll.  I think some very small amount of MKR should be used as collateral, just so MKR is competitive with its peers.  I realize the feedback risks but I imagine that does not come into play if the amount is small enough.
I support listing MKR tokens and setting a small number of DCs, which is good for us. For example: DC = 2.5 million. Even if a black swan event occurs, the damage it brings is very limited.

I agree for MKR as collateral, mainly because DAI market cap is getting far higher than MKR market cap. We also have a bigger stability buffer. Not sure it should be a priority. A DC of 10M is unlikely to change the world (unsure where the risk ceiling is).

One issue here I haven’t seen mentioned on this post (though I’m sure it must be mentioned elsewhere) with allowing users to collateralize MKR is it ultimately puts the governance, and the holders of MKR tokens, at greater risk in the event of a downswing. If you were to try to create a model for the value of an MKR token, it would be directly linked to the safety and amount of assets under collateral in the protocol. In the event of a crypto sell off, we would still expect the value of MKR to decline vs the dollar due to many exchanges using bitcoin to trade for it. However, the price would be somewhat protected as long as our programming didn’t lose money by preforming collateral liquidations. In the event that MKR is heavily collateralized we have two big issues in the event of a downswing based on the fact that we will be forced to further drive down the cost vs the dollar for MKR due to vault liquidations:  our stakeholders will have their purchasing power drastically reduced to the point where they too might have to sell MKR tokens to prevent financial ruin even if our stake holders are not forced to sell, by the platform preforming liquidations of MKR we will be pushing vast amounts onto the market, making it easier for malicious actors to take control of the platform.  I believe the two currency platform functions so well precisely because they are independent of each other. Allowing users to put up MKR for DAI increases our risk while allowing very little extra functionality. As is stated above, there are plenty of places people can collateralize their MKR if they wish to do so, no reason to add fuel to a future forest fire.

Your concerns are valid (and indeed this is the reason MKR has not been included as MCD collateral from the beginning). However, since other platforms allow you to borrow DAI in exchange of MKR, I see the risks you discuss as already (at least to a rather big extent, if not fully) present in our current scenario. In fact, many MKR are available on Aave/Compound and this is the source of the flash-loans governance attacks we had to discuss recently.     SebVentures:  Not sure it should be a priority. A DC of 10M is unlikely to change the world (unsure where the risk ceiling is).   Not a priority, but something to put in the queue? Every new approved collateral is one more tool in the toolbox of MakerDao, and its parameters can be ‘tuned’ whenever we need.

I definitely see where you’re coming from @iammeeoh. I guess my question is what do we gain for adding MKR to the list? Objectively it would grow our potential to issue DAI and allow for more potential users to access the system, but it would also lead to less MKR being available for governing votes. So I’m wondering if it then makes sense that MKR should be one of the last tokens added to the list. We can add others and achieve the same positive outputs without the downside to the safety of our system. Are there other tokens with community interest we can add before MKR so it’ll represent a smaller pool of our total collateral?
If I’m not mistaken, MKR vaults/dsgov could be coded to allow MKR locked in vaults to vote.

iammeeoh:  However, since other platforms allow you to borrow DAI in exchange of MKR, I see the risks you discuss as already (at least to a rather big extent, if not fully) present in our current scenario.   I don’t think the issue is being able to borrow DAI with MKR. The issue is a liquidation loop arising from MKR being a collateral type. If liquidations lower the price of MKR, MKR lent on other platforms might trigger liquidations there, but it won’t trigger additional liquidations at Maker. You can cap the worst case with an extremely small debt ceiling, but then why do it? Shouldn’t collateral types with a completely open DC potential growth be all processed first? It’s not like we have infinite collateral onboarding bandwidth.

I don’t have time for a lengthy comment, but here is an outline.  If MKR were collateral, and MKR underwent a pullback that caused liquidations, then we could see a few undesirable consequences.  The liquidations could cause further MKR price drops and a downward spiral of yet more liquidations.  This means the system accrues bad debt.  That bad debt is handled by first the surplus buffer, and second with flop() debt auctions that will further dilute MKR’s price to attempt to recapitalize the system.  This could, in turn, cause even more liquidations, and down the spiral we go. This would pull MKR out of the governance contract, which would be highly undesirable.  We already have a problem with MKR moving to other lending platforms that threaten the skin-in-the-game mechanism design.  We should be actively encouraging the opposite.  There is certainly a design where we could collateralize the IOU token based on MKR price, which would ensure the MKR holder was locked in the chief, but this is more work than a simple collateral. On the topic of mechanism design, MKR holders should be self-interested profit seekers.  Once they become Vault holders, it’s hard to imagine this isn’t just a case of the fox guarding the hen house.  They are less incentivized to raise rates on themselves when it’s needed to balance the peg or adjust the myriad of other risk parameters appropriately against themselves.  If you’re an MKR holder and a protocol user, ask yourself how many times you let your book dictate your choices in a way that just an MKR holder would have rationally voted for.  These are a few reasons off the top of my head.  I personally try to think of MKR as collateral as roughly equal to printing unbacked DAI.  We have seen the power of MKR to recapitalize the system after a black swan event, we should not mess with that mechanic.

I want to second what Mooney said. Without going into too much detail, the argument that “oh you can borrow Dai against MKR in Aave so why shouldn’t you be able to do it in Maker” is misconstrued. If the price of MKR drops, and liquidations happen on Aave that don’t cover the outstanding debt, then AAVE stakers are on the hook to cover the shortfall. In the case of the case of the Maker Protocol, MKR holders are on the hook through MKR dilutation, which further lowers the price of MKR, potentially generating more MKR liquidations. Because of the different lender of last resort implementations, Aave offering MKR loans does not justify including MKR as collateral in the Maker Protocol. As such I maintain my position that adding MKR to the Maker Protocol is undesirable. Another way to think about it is conflict of interest. MKR holders are essentially insuring the collateral portfolio. Can you really trust MKR holders to insure themselves in a responsible manner when they have every incentive to misprice the risk (too high debt ceiling, too low collateralization ratio, too low stability fee). I sure don’t. As a greedy MKR holder, I could leverage my MKR to generate Dai to invest in this “bull market” and have a stop loss that is essentially the amount of Dai I generated. And If I get liquidated, fine, I lose my MKR, but I’m not the one getting diluted. Do you see how this could be an issue? Every individual MKR holder is incentivized to vote for this, but from a systems perspective this is a disaster.

Aaron_Bartsch:  Great points from both of you! Whenever this gets brought up again (which it will) I will point them to this explanation.   Yes indeed, thank you both, now it is far more clear. I now agree that it’s not a good idea to include MKR as collateral.
I added some more reasons with respect to inventive alignment in my original post.

Having the issues listed above doesn’t mean there isn’t a solution to what is “desired”. I see it like this: MakerDAO lends money (DAI) to anybody with any type of asset, but it cannot lend money to its own owners! Here is where I see the issue, an MKR holder, like anyone else owning another type of asset needs some DAI as well to do something else in some specific moment, and the fact is that ourselves cannot help in that case? Well maybe not the best solution, but sharing some thought on this. Let them borrow from the surplus buffer (maybe not all of it, at least a part), and let them vote from those “vaults”  as well. Don’t add interest to the Surplus buffer, use a percentage of it already as the “collected interest”. This have several consequences:   The MKR there is not really backing the DAI lent (that DAI is already backed by some other collateral).   We create the DAI, and we create the MKR, not needing anybody to do the liquidation, if the system needs to liquidate simply burn those MKR at the price in the oracle plus the 13% liquidation fee, probably this is something more effective than the normal auctions and probabilities of having a bad debt here are lower.   MKR holders wants to borrow more?, well they’ll have to increase the surplus buffer then, or at least the part that can be lent to them.   MKR holders don’t want to increase the fee there? Tricky one, but not impossible to solve, don’t let those having MKR in those vaults to participate in this specific type of vote (ie. in a normal company when there is a decision that benefits a given shareholder, typically the others are the one who can vote for it, and not himself).   Well, not sure if this is that a good of a solution, but adding some Pros:  Increases DAI in circulation (directly from the surplus buffer, or MakerDAO reserves or whatever). Permits that MKR  holders use their assets (MKR) to do other stuff (participate in some nice farming, liquidity pools, others, with the borrowed DAI). MKR holders will prefer to let their MKR here that give them to another protocol like AAVE (reducing the possibility of using that MKR as a flash loan against us). We collect more fees here as well.  Cons:  We need greater Buffers which could be used for this (not sure if this is bad TBH, but it’s a tricky one) The implementation of what was described above it is for sure very complicated!  Well, I could be missing important points here maybe, but letting this around for further discussion

Hello, after some thinking, I came up with a possible solution to allow MKR holders to obtain some DAI in case of need. GOAL: Allow MKR holders to get some DAI without selling their MKR to the market. PROPOSED SOLUTION: We currently have in place a MKR burning mechanism. I propose that a MKR holder could:  send their MKR to the burner The burner, when ready (i.e., when it has enough DAI to spend, a parameter regulated by Governance), ‘burn’ these MKR and sends the DAI (at market price) to the user. –> Note: this avoid buying MKR on the market. No fees/inefficiencies, etc   The burner, however, also sends the user a MKR CALL OPTION (it can have a limited duration) at current market price. During the period of validity of this option, the user can therefore re-buy their MKR from the burner for the same price they sold them earlier to the burner. Of course, if Governance decides, the MKR-holder might be charged a fee for this service.  There are two outcomes: Case 1)  the MKR holder never returns the DAI (i.e., they never use the CALL Option). This is an optimal case: the burner has got/paid the MKR to burn from the MKR-holder, rather than from the market. This is more efficient.  Case 2) the MKR holder eventually (within the period of validity of the CALL option) uses the CALL option and gets back their MKR. This basically undo’s the burning   but ultimately no DAI is lost (in fact, if fees are applied, some money is gained by MakerDAO)  What do you think? It seems to me like this is a relatively low risk approach, given that the money ‘involved’ in this process is capped by the rate/amount of MKR that MakerDAO decides to burn.
I’m not sure that is economically sound. Couldn’t you turn around and buy another MKR with the Dai the protocol just sent you? But now, you also have a free call option from the protocol.

Isn’t Aave allow MRK to Dai now? While it was a great idea to ban MKR to generate Dai, I feel that now competitors took the market. And instead of protected something that is not protectable anymore we lost market share.

IMHO, I believe Maker can be ‘late’, sometimes, but ultimately has a positional advantage over competitors: we can print both MKR and DAI. The PSM is a great example. So if we design things properly, making the best of this positional advantage, we can come back and regain market share.

I am only worried that even if Maker was to onboard MKR as collateral, both DC and LR would be set so conservatively (because of reasons mentioned many times before) that nobody would use it or benefits would be limited.
